ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course is a lot of work for a seminar, as it is a book a week, and a four hour time commitment. However, it was definitely one of the more interesting classes that I have taken at Yale, with a diverse group of students. It was interesting to have three professors at once - sometimes it made logistics interesting, but mostly we benefited from it. As someone with no background in environmental studies, I was pleasantly surprised at how well many of the topics fit in with other things I have studied in politics and history. The different perspective enriched my understanding of class, the state, social movements, etc.

A series of somewhat disconnected discussions/studies of issues pertaining to agrarian societies, with focus heavily on modern concerns. I would recommend this course to other students for the breadth of information and methodological approaches contained in the readings.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course added to my knowledge of anthropology and political science, both fields that I knew little about. Unclear how this will contribute to my dissertation/research.
